perturbation.original_text: This Agreement may be terminated at any time, without the payment of any penalty, with respect to any series or the Trust, by the Board of Trustees of the Trust, or by the Sponsor, in each case on not less than 60 days' written notice to the other party.
perturbation.changed_text: This Agreement may be terminated at any time, without the payment of any penalty, with respect to any series or the Trust, by the Board of Trustees of the Trust, or by the Sponsor, in each case on not less than 10 days' written notice to the other party.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the termination notice period to 10 days may violate regulations requiring longer notice periods for contract terminations, particularly in contexts involving significant financial services agreements.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 15(a)(4) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 requires that investment advisory contracts (which this sponsorship agreement effectively functions as) continue in effect for a period more than two years from its date only so long as such continuance is specifically approved at least annually by the board of directors or by vote of a majority of the outstanding voting securities of such company. A 10-day termination clause makes such continuance impossible as it permits termination without regard to this approval requirement.

Contracts of advisers and underwriters (a) Written contract to serve or act as investment adviser; contents It shall be unlawful for any person to serve or act as investment adviser of a registered investment company, except pursuant to a written contract, which contract, whether with such registered company or with an investment adviser of such registered company, ha
perturbation.justification: The changed text reduces the termination notice period from 60 to 10 days, which potentially contradicts Section 15(a)(4) of the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Law Explanation suggests that a 10-day termination clause could prevent the required annual approval by the board of directors. Scraped Law Snippet 1 mentions 15 USC 80a-15, which pertains to contracts of advisers and underwriters. Scraped Law Snippet 2 also lists 15 USC 80a-15 within the Investment Company Act of 1940, further confirming its relevance. Although the snippets do not specify the minimum required notice period, the Law Explanation claims that a shorter notice period undermines the annual approval requirement, thus a contradiction score of 0.7 is warranted.

perturbation.original_text: For the services to be rendered and facilities to be provided by the Sponsor hereunder, the Trust shall pay Domini a fee accrued daily and payable monthly at an annual rate equal to 0.50% of the Trust's average daily net assets for the Trust's then current fiscal year.
perturbation.changed_text: For the services to be rendered and facilities to be provided by the Sponsor hereunder, the Trust shall pay Domini a fee accrued daily and payable quarterly in arrears at an annual rate equal to 0.50% of the Trust's average daily net assets for the Trust's then current fiscal year.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment frequency to quarterly introduces potential conflicts with requirements for timely payment in financial contracts.
perturbation.law_explanation: While this is not a wage agreement, changing payment from monthly to quarterly could lead to a violation of similar requirements of the Massachusetts Wage Act, M.G.L. c. 149, § 148, for timely and regular payments, if this is construed as a service agreement, because it provides a less frequent schedule of payments.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: General Law - Part I, Title XXI, Chapter 149, Section 148 Skip to Content General Laws Part I ADMINISTRATION OF THE GOVERNMENT Title XXI LABOR AND INDUSTRIES Chapter 149 LABOR AND INDUSTRIES Section 148 Payment of wages; commissions; exemption by contract; persons deemed employers; provision for cashing check or draft; violation of statute Section 148 Search Search the Legislature Search General Laws Go Directly to a General Law Chapter Section Go to General Law Skip to Content Print Page Prev ious Next Section 148: Payment of wages; commissions; exemption by contract; persons deemed employers; provision for cashing check or draft; violation of statute Section 148. Every person having employees in his service shall pay weekly or bi-weekly each such employee the wages earned by him to within six days of the termination of the pay period during which the wages were earned if employed for five or six days in a calendar week, or to within seven days of the termination of the pay period during which the wages were earned if such employee is employed seven days in a calendar week, or in the case of an employee who has worked for a period of less than five days, hereinafter called a casual employee, shall, within seven days after the termination of such period, pay the wages earned by such casual employee during such period, but any employee leaving his employment shall be paid in full on the following regular pay day, and, in the absence of a regular pay day, on the following Saturday; and any employee discharged from such employment shall be paid in full on the day of his discharge, or in Boston as soon as the laws requiring pay rolls, bills and accounts to be certified shall have been complied with; and the commonwealth, its departments, officers, boards and commissions shall so pay every mechanic, workman and laborer employed by it or them, and every person employed in any other capacity by it or them in any penal or charitable institution, and every county and city shall so pay every employee engaged in its business the wag
perturbation.justification: The change from monthly to quarterly payments introduces a potential contradiction with Massachusetts Wage Act M.G.L. c. 149, § 148 if the agreement is construed as a service agreement. The Law Explanation suggests this possibility. Scraped Law Snippet 1 states that "Every person having employees in his service shall pay weekly or bi-weekly each such employee the wages earned by him". While the original text doesn't explicitly violate this, the changed text increases the time between payments, potentially conflicting with the spirit of ensuring timely payment to those providing services, resulting in a moderate contradiction. The absence of a second snippet limits a stronger assessment.

perturbation.original_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Sponsor shall not be deemed to have assumed, pursuant to this Agreement, any duties with respect to, and shall not be responsible for, the management of the Trust's assets or the rendering of investment advice and supervision with respect thereto or the distribution of shares of any series, nor shall the Sponsor be deemed to have assumed or have any responsibility with respect to functions specifically assumed by any transfer agent, custodian, fund accounting pricing agent or shareholder servicing agent of the Trust.
perturbation.changed_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Sponsor shall not be deemed to have assumed, pursuant to this Agreement, any duties with respect to, and shall not be responsible for, the management of the Trust's assets, however, the sponsor shall be responsible for rendering of investment advice and supervision with respect thereto or the distribution of shares of any series, nor shall the Sponsor be deemed to have assumed or have any responsibility with respect to functions specifically assumed by any transfer agent, custodian, fund accounting pricing agent or shareholder servicing agent of the Trust.
perturbation.explanation: Making the Sponsor now responsible for rendering investment advice creates a potential contradiction. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 imposes specific registration and compliance requirements on investment advisors. If the Sponsor now provides investment advice without proper registration, this section will directly violate law.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 203(a) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 makes it unlawful for any investment advisor to make use of the mails or any means or instrumentality of interstate commerce in connection with his or its business as an investment advisor, unless such investment advisor is registered under section 203. Rendering investment advice without registering first breaks this rule.

Registration of investment advisers (a) Necessity of registration Except as provided in subsection (b) and section 80b–3a of this title , it shall be unlawful for any investment adviser, unless registered under this section, to make use of the mails or any means or instrumentality of interstate commerce in connection with his or its business as an investment
perturbation.justification: The changed text makes the Sponsor responsible for "rendering of investment advice and supervision," which directly implicates the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. The provided Law Explanation states that Section 203(a) of the Act makes it unlawful for an investment advisor to use interstate commerce in connection with their business unless registered. Scraped Law Snippet 1, referencing 15 USC 80b-3(a), confirms this, stating it is unlawful for an investment advisor to make use of mails or any means of interstate commerce unless registered. Since the changed text now assigns investment advisory duties to the Sponsor, and registration is required under 15 USC 80b-3(a) to perform such duties lawfully, there is a strong potential contradiction if the Sponsor is not registered as an investment advisor. Thus, the contradiction score is 0.8.
